The New England Journal of Medicine reports that men who smoke risk cutting 7.3 years off their lives.
 
 Oxford University's International Journal of Epidemiology reports "Life expectancy at age 20 for gay and bisexual men is 8 to 20 years less than for all men...nearly half of gay and bisexual men currently aged 20 will not reach their 65th birthday."
 
 Judging by the number of years at risk, homosexual activity is up to three times deadlier than smoking. Click on this link http://www.afa.net/homosexual_agenda/ha031901.asp and then click on the Oxford University link to get to the stats.
 
 What's causing nearly half of all gay and bisexual men to not reach their 65th birthday? What's making their lifestyle more deadly than smoking?
 
 1.) HIV/AIDS impacts on mortality rates for gay and bisexual men(At the Oxford Link).
 
 The HIV/AIDS problem is caused by these things:

 http://www.cdc.gov/od/oc/media/pressrel/r030728a.htm
 
 This lifestyle is a dangerous one and should not be promoted as a healthy, safe alternative. Want to push the odds to nearly 50% that you will NOT make it to 65? Want an early death?Then embrace the gay and bisexual lifestyle.

 AIDS is not just a gay disease...
 
 :: Sub- Sahara Africa 
 In 2003, 26.6 million people were living with HIV, including 3.2 million who became infected in the past 12 months. AIDS killed approximately 2.3 million people in the same year. This made the region by far the worst-affected by the HIV/AIDS epidemic. Women are more likely to be infected than men. 
 In South Africa , the average rate of HIV prevalence in pregnant women attending antenatal clinics was about 25 percent. It is estimated that 5.3 million South Africans were living with HIV at the end of 2002. Because it is a relatively recent epidemic, and given current trends, AIDS deaths will continue to increase rapidly over the next five years. 
 In four neighboring countries, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia and Swaziland, HIV prevalence has reached extremely high levels without signs of leveling off. Infection rates in Botswana and Swaziland are around 39 percent. HIV prevalence in antenatal sites in Namibia rose to over 23 percent in 2002. Lesotho's most recent data shows median HIV prevalence among antenatal clinic attendees climbing to 30 percent.
 http://www.worldbank.org/worldaidsday/charts.htm
 
 http://www.worldvision.org.nz/news/archive/20020717-01.asp

The CDC links that I gave shed new light on the dangers of gay and bisexual sex.

 First of all, you're not talking about gay and bisexual people in general, you're only talking about men, because none of the stats you have are about gay or bisexual women. Also, your statistics are not global, but regional, mostly to the US (where few of the global HIV/AIDS cases are located). Which means you are then only talking to gay/bisexual American men sexually active with multiple partners without condoms. 
 
 Second, death rates in America from AIDS dropped sharply in 1995 with the advent of new drug cocktails, which have made an HIV positive diagnosis in the US for anyone with medical care no longer a death sentence. This is not the case for the majoritarily heterosexual HIV-positive people in countries elsewhere in the world, due to Pharmaceutical monopolies' criminilization of the distribution of generic life-saving drugs to populations in need.
 
 Third, in order to avoid this "early death", gay and bisexual American men have only to practice safer sex, just like every else. Which makes your point completely moot.
 
 Conclusion: if you want to avoid an early death, wear a condom.
